section.title: Can we avoid \Bbb C?
section.p: Short answer: No! Why we cannot avoid dealing with complex numbers is a non-trivial question with many answers from different fields. The one we will provide here is the very first one that appeared in literature and that lead directly to the development of the study of this very field of study.

Complex numbers appeared for the first time in literature in 16-th century in connection with the problem of solving 3-rd degree polynomial equations. The history of the discovery of this celebrated formula is quite complicated (the curious reader can get many full details in the increasingly more detailed publications , , ) and involves several of the strongest mathematicians of that century: Scipione del Ferro, Niccol√≤ Tartaglia and Gerolamo Cardano.

According to Cardano's favorite pupil, L. Ferrari (to whom, incidentally, is due the formula for the solution of 4-th degree polynomial equations), the formula first appeared in a publication of del Ferro, now lost, dating about 1515 but the book that most contributed to make them available to the mathematical community is Cardano's Ars Magna. Published in Latin in 1545 (see for a translation in English), this book is considered one of the greatest scientific treatises of the early Renaissance.

In his Ars Magna, Cardano noticed that, in some particular case(s? **because of the word some), his formula included the square root of a negative number, even though (some/all?) solutions are real. He called (this/these?) cases irreducible. One can now check this easily as follows. It was well-known, even during Cardano's time, the quadratic term of the general cubic equation x^3+ax^2+bx+c=0 can be eliminated by the translation y=x-a/3 to consider, WLOG, the so-called depressed cubic x^3+px+q=0. In 1680, Ehrenfried Walther von Tschirnhausen started experimenting with higher degrees using transformations hoping to find a resolution formula for quintics. In case of cubics, his idea amounts to setting y-(x^2+rx+s)=0 and to determine y so that the resultant of the polynomials (in x) at the l.h.s. of Eqs. and is zero, namely the two equations have a common root.
Rafael Bombelli, 1526-1572
The resultant is a cubic polynomial in y and the two degrees of freedom r and s can be chosen so that the coefficients of its terms of degree 1 and 2 are zero:
var('x,y,p,q,r,s') cb = x^3 + p*x + q res = cb.resultant(y-x^2-r*x-s,x).poly(y) sol = solve([res.coefficient(y,1),res.coefficient(y,2)], [r,s], solution_dict=True) (res,sol)
(q*r^3 - p*r^2*s + p*q*r - p^2*s - 3*q*r*s + 2*p*s^2 - s^3 + (2*p - 3*s)*y^2 + y^3 - q^2 + (p*r^2 + p^2 + 3*q*r - 4*p*s + 3*s^2)*y, [{r: -1/6*(9*q + sqrt(12*p^3 + 81*q^2))/p, s: 2/3*p}, {r: -1/6*(9*q - sqrt(12*p^3 + 81*q^2))/p, s: 2/3*p}])
The problem is the square root in the expression of r: a cubic has always at least a real root but when 4a^3+27b^2 \lt 0 this method expresses even that root through complex numbers! In particular, 4a^3+27b^2 is always negative when Eq. has a single root, namely when its local maximum and minimum have the same sign. Cardano tried unsuccesfully for the rest of his life to find a formula without this problem. In fact, it was proved three centuries later [add ref!!!] that there is no way to avoid the appearance of complex numbers in the resolution formulae for cubics and quartics.

A contemporary of Cardano, named Rafael Bombelli, decided instead to embrace this feature of the solving formula for cubic (and quartic) polynomials and started the study of the algebra of what are now known as complex numbers. In particular, his main work "L'Algebra" is considered the book where complex numbers where first introduced in literature; it is in this book that appear first the signs rules for the multiplication of any two among \pm1,\pm i. More information on Bombelli and his work can be found in , and .

section.title: Construction of \Bbb C
section.p:
From elementary Algebra, we know the imaginary unit, i, has property i^2=-1. \Bbb C is an extension field of the \Bbb R, which means \Bbb C inherits the arithmetic operations from \Bbb R, addition, subtraction, multiplication and division by any complex number except 0. If we multiply i by  eta then add \alpha, where  eta,\alpha \in \Bbb R, we consider \alpha the real part and  eta the imaginary part obtaining the complex number \alpha + i eta. If say \alpha = 0, then the complex number is purely imaginary. The only number that is a real number and purely imaginary is zero. We also say that two complex numbers are equal if and only if they have the same real and imaginary parts. We not look at the extended operations on \Bbb C.

We can see that \gamma^2 + \delta^2 \in \Bbb R, so we can solve the division operation easily by multiplying by \gamma - i\delta, which will cancel the imaginary unit since i^2=-1. So,  rac{(\alpha + i eta)}{(\gamma + i\delta)} =  rac{(\alpha + i eta)(\gamma - i\delta)}{(\gamma + i\delta)(\gamma - i\delta)} = ( rac{\alpha\gamma + \delta eta}{\gamma^2 + \delta^2}) + i( rac{ eta\gamma - \alpha\delta}{(\gamma^2 + \delta^2)}). We can use this same process to find the special case of the reciprocal of a complex number to be  rac{1}{\alpha + i eta}= rac{\alpha -i eta}{\alpha^2 +  eta^2}. As mentioned, i^2=-1. This leads to i^3=i^2\cdot i=-i, i^4=i^2 \cdot i^2=-1\cdot-1=1=i^0. From this, we can observe that the multiplication of i to itself n times, where n is an integer, is equivalent to either 1, i, -1, and -i which corresponds when n = \{0,1,2,3\}. So we can say if n\mod 4 = 0, then i^n=1, if n\mod 4 = 1, then i^n=i, if n\mod 4 = 2, then i^n=-1, and finally if n\mod 4 = 3, then i^n=-i.
This is exactly the formula for the (n + 1)th case.

This method of proof is known as mathematical induction. Instead of attempting to verify a statement about some subset S of the positive integers {\mathbb N} on a case-by-case basis, an impossible task if S is an infinite set, we give a specific proof for the smallest integer being considered, followed by a generic argument showing that if the statement holds for a given case, then it must also hold for the next case in the sequence. We summarize mathematical induction in the following axiom.

statement.p: Let S(n) be a statement about integers for n \in {\mathbb N} and suppose S(n_0) is true for some integer n_0. If for all integers k with k \geq n_0, S(k) implies that S(k+1) is true, then S(n) is true for all integers n greater than or equal to n_0.

example.title: An Inequality for Powers of 2
example.p: For all integers n \geq 3, 2^n \gt n + 4. Since 8 = 2^3 \gt 3 + 4 = 7, the statement is true for n_0 = 3. Assume that 2^k \gt k + 4 for k \geq 3. Then 2^{k + 1} = 2 \cdot 2^{k} \gt 2(k + 4). But 2(k + 4) = 2k + 8 \gt k + 5 = (k + 1) + 4 since k is positive. Hence, by induction, the statement holds for all integers n \geq 3.

example.title: Some Integers Divisible by 9
example.p: Every integer 10^{n + 1} + 3 \cdot 10^n + 5 is divisible by 9 for n \in {\mathbb N}. For n = 1, 10^{1 + 1} + 3 \cdot 10 + 5 = 135 = 9 \cdot 15 is divisible by 9. Suppose that 10^{k + 1} + 3 \cdot 10^k + 5 is divisible by 9 for k \geq 1. Then 10^{(k + 1) + 1} + 3 \cdot 10^{k + 1} + 5& = 10^{k + 2} + 3 \cdot 10^{k + 1} + 50 - 45 & = 10 (10^{k + 1} + 3 \cdot 10^{k} + 5) - 45 is divisible by 9.

section.p: We have an equivalent statement of the Principle of Mathematical Induction that is often very useful.

statement.p: Let S(n) be a statement about integers for n \in {\mathbb N} and suppose S(n_0) is true for some integer n_0. If S(n_0), S(n_0 + 1), \ldots, S(k) imply that S(k + 1) for k \geq n_0, then the statement S(n) is true for all integers n \geq n_0.

section.p: A nonempty subset S of {\mathbb Z} is well-orderedWell-ordered set if S contains a least element. Notice that the set {\mathbb Z} is not well-ordered since it does not contain a smallest element. However, the natural numbers are well-ordered.

statement.p: Every nonempty subset of the natural numbers is well-ordered.

section.p: The Principle of Well-Ordering is equivalent to the Principle of Mathematical Induction.

statement.p: The Principle of Mathematical Induction implies that 1 is the least positive natural number.

proof.p: Let S = \{ n \in {\mathbb N} : n \geq 1 \}. Then 1 \in S. Now assume that n \in S; that is, n \geq 1. Since n+1 \geq 1, n+ 1 \in S; hence, by induction, every natural number is greater than or equal to 1.

statement.p: The Principle of Mathematical Induction implies the Principle of Well-Ordering. That is, every nonempty subset of \mathbb N contains a least element.

proof.p: We must show that if S is a nonempty subset of the natural numbers, then S contains a least element. If S contains 1, then the theorem is true by . Assume that if S contains an integer k such that 1 \leq k \leq n, then S contains a least element. We will show that if a set S contains an integer less than or equal to n + 1, then S has a least element. If S does not contain an integer less than n+1, then n+1 is the smallest integer in S. Otherwise, since S is nonempty, S must contain an integer less than or equal to n. In this case, by induction, S contains a least element.

section.p:
Induction can also be very useful in formulating definitions. For instance, there are two ways to define n!, the factorial of a positive integer n.
The explicit definition: n! = 1 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdots (n - 1) \cdot n.
The inductive or recursive definition: 1! = 1 and n! = n(n - 1)! for n \gt 1.
Every good mathematician or computer scientist knows that looking at problems recursively, as opposed to explicitly, often results in better understanding of complex issues.

statement.p: One method of computing all of the prime numbers less than a certain fixed positive integer N is to list all of the numbers n such that 1 \lt n \lt N. Begin by eliminating all of the multiples of 2. Next eliminate all of the multiples of 3. Now eliminate all of the multiples of 5. Notice that 4 has already been crossed out. Continue in this manner, noticing that we do not have to go all the way to N; it suffices to stop at \sqrt{N}. Using this method, compute all of the prime numbers less than N = 250. We can also use this method to find all of the integers that are relatively prime to an integer N. Simply eliminate the prime factors of N and all of their multiples. Using this method, find all of the numbers that are relatively prime to N= 120. Using the Sieve of Eratosthenes, write a program that will compute all of the primes less than an integer N.

Let {\mathbb N}^0 = {\mathbb N} \cup \{ 0 \}. Ackermann's function is the function A :{\mathbb N}^0 \times {\mathbb N}^0 \rightarrow {\mathbb N}^0 defined by the equations A(0, y) & = y + 1 A(x + 1, 0) & = A(x, 1) A(x + 1, y + 1) & = A(x, A(x + 1, y)) .

Use this definition to compute A(3, 1). Write a program to evaluate Ackermann's function. Modify the program to count the number of statements executed in the program when Ackermann's function is evaluated. How many statements are executed in the evaluation of A(4, 1)? What about A(5, 1)?

Write a computer program that will implement the Euclidean algorithm. The program should accept two positive integers a and b as input and should output \gcd( a,b) as well as integers r and s such that \gcd( a,b) = ra + sb.
